Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Embedded DSP with Underwater Renewable Energy: Towards Sustainability for Cyber-Aquatic Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dedicated digital signal processing (DSP) is a key technology for a diversity of embedded applications. Recently, underwater autonomous distributed systems have received growing interest in aquatic observation and exploration. These systems pose significant challenges for sustainable signal processing due to the high communication cost and new constraints on energy supply in the harsh underwater environment. The relatively mature and predictable energy harvesting techniques are either not applicable in the underwater environment or do not offer sufficient capabilities. This raises dual challenges to the design of dedicated DSP for cyber-aquatic systems with respect to what alternative energy sources are available and how to effectively and reliably utilize renewable energy.

This CAREER project seeks to overcome these challenges arising at the cyber-aquatic interface. The goal is to develop a new DSP design framework that allows dynamic tuning of system complexity/performance and energy-efficiency levels in adaptation with renewable underwater energy sources. The results from this research will enable sustainable cyber-aquatic systems that have great potential for innovations but have remained largely unexplored so far. Design tools and optimization methods developed from this project can be applied to a wide range of embedded applications powered by various energy sources.

The education component of this project seeks to strengthen interdisciplinary education through a dynamic curriculum that builds on this research project. Through industry collaboration and outreach programs at UConn, this project will offer research opportunities to students especially women and underrepresented minority students, and enhance engineering awareness and interests among high-school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research establishes the fundamental principles for energy-adaptive signal processing paradigms by which a unified energy-performance framework facilitates the deep coupling of energy harvesting devices, hardware platforms, and signal processing algorithms. Reliable and energy-efficient digital signal processors (DSP) powered by environmental energy will benefit a host of applications such as micro-robotic networks, smart and connected communities, environmental protection, body-area sensor networks, and Internet of Things (IoT). Dedicated digital signal processors are a key component in these applications. This research investigates statistical methods for characterization of non-deterministic renewable energy sources from the system design perspective. Since the inherent uncertainties in energy availability strongly affect the way in which the energy can be used, understanding the related system implications is critical for DSP systems to achieve sustainable performance. This research develops an energy-adaptive signal processing framework to dynamically adjust the system performance in adaptation with the changing renewable energy level. By considering the non-linear relationship between the performance and energy consumption inherent in the signal processing systems, a progressive performance tuning technique was developed to deal with the dynamic constraints of unstable energy supply at runtime. It was demonstrated that, by dynamically adjusting the algorithm settings, the overall system performance can be improved to a level beyond the existing systems. The developed techniques from these research can be applied to a wide range of embedded systems with various energy sources. In particular, this research investigates the microbial energy harvesting technology in large-scale benthic environment. Several energy harvesting devices with different scales/complexities have been developed, and energy harvesting performance have been tested and characterized. Field tests were also conducted at the Long Island Sound, Avery Point, CT, which demonstrated the reliable and sufficient power output that could potentially be utilized by underwater sensor networks. This work develops fundamental principles and methodologies that bridge computational/cyber and physical layers. It explores a new research area that has a great potential for innovations but remain largely unexplored.
